question.title: Call method with button on Android Action Bar

node.contents: Do you have an instance of the DrawView in the MainActivity? So did you create the DrawView object anywhere in your MainActivity?

node.contents: I have two classes at the moment, MainActivity and DrawView. The DrawView is working fine and creating a canvas that allows me to draw lines. What I have no idea how to do is when I click the button I've placed on the Action Bar it saves whatever is drawn on the canvas as an image.

astNode.text: I have two classes at the moment, MainActivity and DrawView. The DrawView is working fine and creating a canvas that allows me to draw lines. What I have no idea how to do is when I click the button I've placed on the Action Bar it saves whatever is drawn on the canvas as an image.

node.contents: I don't know how to use the segment of code below from my MainActivity class. Do I need to create a new class with a method in it or can I create the method within the MainActivity class (in relation to the line "//method goes here")? I'm also assuming I have to retrieve the canvas object, from DrawView, and pass it to the method as a parameter. How do I do that when it's in the DrawView object?

node.contents: Invoke method from your action bar button and write code for save in that method . if method is in other class use static keyword to call that method and define that method static or you can create class object to access it.

astNode.text: Invoke method from your action bar button and write code for save in that method . if method is in other class use static keyword to call that method and define that method static or you can create class object to access it.

node.contents: Thanks Tim. I hadn't made the canvas object public in DrawView. I'll see if I can convert to a png file and save it with a method now that I can pass it as a parameter.

node.contents: Now you can access the drawView variable in your onOptionsItemSelected method. This means that you can access all public variables in that class. If you store your draw path in a public variable you can access it. You can do that by making the canvas a public field in your DrawView class. Just like you made the DrawView a private field in your MainActivity class.

astNode.text: Now you can access the drawView variable in your onOptionsItemSelected method. This means that you can access all public variables in that class. If you store your draw path in a public variable you can access it. You can do that by making the canvas a public field in your DrawView class. Just like you made the DrawView a private field in your MainActivity class.
